Rotary is on Instagram. Check out some favorites from our photographers!   Take a trip back in time on Throwback Thursdays (#tbt) with this photo from our archives of a Rotary Club of Chicago outing to Jackson Park in Chicago on 10 September 1910.   Photo courtesy of #Rotary International

Polly Hincks contracted polio in 1951 when she was pregnant. Polio brings terror  she said.  After months of rehab  she was again able to walk unassisted. But it wasn't until a year ago  that she discovered all #Rotary has done to eradicate #polio. She knew she wanted to join and be a part of it.   Throughout October  we will be running blog posts from polio survivors and volunteers working alongside us to put an end to polio. What your stories about polio?  Read more of Polly's story on Rotary Voices.

Rotary changed Shafi Parekh's life when a bald 9-year-old girl in a pediatric oncology unit of the National Institute of Child Health in Karachi  Pakistan  tugged at his trouser leg and thanked him. "I tried  but I could not help crying and hugging that child " he said.  Shafi was at the opening of a lab that had been donated via Rotary through the Rotary Club of Madera  the Association of Pakistani Physicians in North America  and  what was then his club  the Rotary Club of Karachi Sunset Millennium in Pakistan.  The experience prompted him to do more. The next year he got five clubs in northern Italy to help provide surgical equipment to remove tumors. One year later  the hospital had the equipment it required to save countless lives.  Help tell Rotary's story. Post on your social media how #Rotary has changed your life.

Elsa Soto Garcia  a member of the Rotaract Club of Mexicali Industrial  Mexico  was one of 4 000 model UN participants to be selected for a week-long training program at the United Nations in New York City. Through their involvement in model UN  Elsa and other Rotary members in California support Rotary’s mission of promoting peace.   Read more about the program in her blog post for Rotary Voices.

First Harvest  a project led by Rotarians in Seattle  Washington  USA  works to connect children and young professionals to #Rotary. Learn more about their work to help feed the hungry in Rotary Leader.

#Rotary clubs worldwide are looking at some of the best ways to make room for the next generation of young professionals and volunteers in clubs.  What's your advice? You can read what Rotaractors and Rotarians said.

The first-ever Rotaract Model United Nations in Romania attracted young professionals from 10 countries to meet  work together  and debate some of the world's most pressing international issues.   In #Rotary Voices  learn how the event empowered young leaders to shape the future.

By doing some strategic planning and engaging people with online content and club activities that were interesting  one #Rotary club in Australia added 80 members in three years - - without a big advertising budget.  Read how members of Rotary of Crawley incorporated social media and other activities into their club's communications to their community.

#Polio is highly contagious disease without a cure. If we don't end polio  10 million children in the next 40 years could get the disease  said Emmy-award winning actress Archie Panjabi  who stars in The Good Wife.  She was interviewed by for Forbes by social entrepreneur and Rotarian Devin Thorpe.   Join us on World Polio Day  24 October. Educate friends and family about polio. With the Center for Global Health at Northwestern University  #Rotary will livestream a global update on the status of polio eradication.   Plan to watch and learn more at www.forbes.com/sites/devinthorpe/2013/09/25/archie-panjabi-of-the-good-wife-says-rotary-is-this-close-to-ending-polio/

Joining Rotary changed my life for the better  said Chris Jones  of the Rotary Club of Lake Norman Huntersville  North Carolina  USA.  "Being a Rotarian has enabled me to create life-lasting friendships of some outstanding and highly ethical people  given me a mechanism to make gifts to The Rotary Foundation  and become more compassionate toward others. It has been one of the best parts of my life."  How has #Rotary changed your life? It's Social Media Week (#smw13). Share it on social media and ask someone new to visit your club!

How do you keep a roomful of students and adults awake for leadership training? Rotary members in California  USA  found that by taking their leadership seminar out of the classroom and introducing teambuilding exercises  they were able to keep people from nodding off and more engaged.   Learn more about this innovative approach in Bill Tobin's post for #Rotary Voices.

Rotary has definitely changed my life  said Klaus J. Schuler  who has belonged to a #Rotary club in Belgium and now belongs to a club in Stuttgart  Germany.   "The global community welcomes you wherever you are " he said. Also  "the opportunity to improve conditions for life for many through big and small  local and global projects is an immense contribution."  Klaus partners with Rotarians from several clubs to deliver bicycles to low-income children in South Africa.  How has Rotary changed your life? It's Social Media Week (#smw13). Share it on social media and ask someone to join  Rotary!

We love #Rotary because of our Rotary members and all of our friends of Rotary  such as Rotaractors  alumni  and other partners who create positive changes in communities worldwide.  Why do you love Rotary? Share it on social media. It's Social Media Week (#smw13)!

Rotary changed my life  said Tamara Yankovich. It "helped me to understand that the world is much bigger than single individuals  and that through leveraging the strengths and contributions of many  unimaginable greatness and betterment can be achieved."  Rotary also taught her how to use her skills to help others as well as mutual respect and trust.  What have you learned through #Rotary? Share it on social media from 23 to 27 September during Social Media Week (#smw13).   Tamara is pictured in the photo with her husband  Ian Swainson.  Both were members of the Rotary Club of Petawawa  in Petawawa  Ontario  Canada.

People can't join a Rotary club if they don't know about it! Go to where your potential members are and tell them about the benefits of Rotary. Talk about your club on #social media as well as advertise your club on billboards -- for free.   Penny Offer shares how Rotary members in Canada sought out companies and made the most of digital billboards on busy roads to get free or low-cost ad space. Learn more in her blog post for #Rotary Voices.

What are you doing on World #Polio Day  24 October?   You can get suggestions by listening to our free webinar  "How You Can Help Eradicate Polio " at www.rotary.org/en/learning-reference/webinars/on-demand

Virgilio Medina from Brazil first encountered #Rotary when he was a Rotary Youth Exchange student and visited the United States. "I met so wonderful people  which made a great impact in my whole life " he said.  He's now member of the Rotary Club of Rio de Janeiro-São Conrado and has worked on projects to help disadvantaged children.  How has your life been changed by #Rotary? Share it on social media from 23 to 27 September during Social Media Week (#smw13).  Pictured is Virgilio with Rotarians from Niles  Ohio  USA  where he had his Youth Exchange more than 40 years ago.
Get the most out of the new rotary.org. Learn more in the latest issue of #Rotary Leader.

It's Social Media Week (#smw13) 23-27 September.    Rotarians  members of Rotaract  and friends of #Rotary  share your Facebook page information so people can like your page and learn about how you're making a difference in your community.  Watch this video to learn about the power of social media and Rotary!

Happy International Day of Peace (#peaceday)!  If you're interested in peace and conflict resolution  take action and make a difference through #Rotary. Apply for our #Peace Center scholarships at https://www.rotary.org/en/peace-fellowships or give to Rotary and peace at https://www.rotary.org/en/give.

Where can you have fun in the sun  play in the sand  see giant sand sculptures  and raise money for local libraries all at the same time? The Rotaract Club of Long Beach's annual sand sculpture contest!   See how Rotaractors are supporting education and raising Rotary's public image in Katie Gaston's blog post for #Rotary Voices.

21 September is the International Day of Peace (#peaceday). Share Rotary's story  and tell your friends and family on social media how #Rotary is working for #peace.   Learn more at www.rotary.org/en/peace-fellowships and at Rotary Peace Centers.

How are you celebrating the International Day of Peace (#peaceday) on 21 September? How can we bring more peace in the world and our community?  You can contribute to peace -- and #Rotary -- at https://www.rotary.org/en/give. #Rotarypeace

At the May 2013 #Rotary Global Peace Forum in Hiroshima  Japan  2012-13 RI President Sakuji Tanaka was presented with this Berlin Peace Clock for "the global service for peace and reconciliation undertaken by Rotary International."   Get ready for International Day of Peace on 21 September (#peaceday) by learning more about the Berlin Peace Clocks at www.berliner-friedensuhr.de. Select your language by clicking on the flags on the bottom of the page.  If you're not a Rotarian and interested in peace and conflict resolution or know someone who is  contact your local Rotary club to find out about how to be a Rotary Peace Fellow and make a difference in the world. Learn more at www.rotary.org/en/peace-fellowships #rotarypeace

We are saddened by the loss of Frank Kohler  of the Rotary Club of Lexington Park  Rotary Club #5892  USA  as well as his coworkers at the Washington Navy Yard on 16 September. Our thoughts are with his family  friends  and fellow Rotarians who are coping with the loss.   Kohler has been a member of #Rotary since 1998.

Records the Nazis looted from Dutch #Rotary clubs are safely back in the hands of the Netherlands Rotary Foundation. Rabbi Mark Glickman  whose wife is a Rotary club member  uncovered this interesting chapter in history while researching his book on Nazi pillaging.   Read more in Rotary Voices.

Rotarians made an "audacious" move about 25 years ago in an effort to End Polio Now: "They created a partnership between a private network of volunteers and a public health initiative."  Read more in The Globe and Mail about how #Rotary works to eradicate #polio and how when we set our mind on something  it's hard to turn us away!
Take a look at a brief video about www.rotary.org and how it can help those who want to learn more about Rotary  such as how to find a club  the benefits of #Rotary in communities  and scholarships.

Rotary has a longstanding partnership with Dolly Parton's Imagination Library. Clubs across Canada  the United Kingdom  the United States  and recently Australia have helped put books in the hands of small children. In honor of International Literacy Day  Dollywood Foundation President David Dotson shares how thankful he is for this partnership in the latest blog post for #Rotary Voices.
It's not too late to join us for our 12 September webinar to get ideas for celebrating World #Polio Day  24 October. How is your #Rotary or Rotaract club celebrating?

Every year  6.9 million children die before reaching their fifth birthday. Almost two-thirds of them -- 4.4 million -- die of infectious diseases  nearly all of which could have been prevented.  What would happen if 1.2 million Rotarians continued their service efforts in water  sanitation  health  hunger  and literacy  but with children in mind?  Read more from The #Rotary Foundation chair at http://ow.ly/oE0lr. You can give to our Foundation at http://www.rotary.org/en/give.

The Rotary Club of Glen Eira  Australia  has been busy in its 25 years of existence. But it wasn't until this year  when everyone in the club pitched in to pull off the first-ever Caulfield Racecourse Run that it became real. Read more about their event  and see how putting on a special fundraiser can energize your club.

Polio eradication is the latest fashion trend in Brazil. End Polio Now T-shirts were making a fashion statement during a party in August thrown by FORUM Tufi Duek for top model Isabelli Fontana  the latest celebrity to lend her voice to Rotary's #polio eradication campaign.   Read more in our blog  #Rotary Voices.

In September  for New Generations Month  celebrate all the ways #Rotary develops young leaders by sharing your experiences on social media. Let the world know how you Engage Rotary  Change Lives by using these hash tags:  •           1-7 September - #EngageRotaract •           8-14 September - #EngageYouthExchange •           15-21 September - #EngageRYLA  •           22-18 September - #EngageInteract

In 1988 there were 350 000 cases of #polio  and within the last year there have been less than 250 cases reported  said Dr. John Sever. Everyone's help is needed to end polio. If polio is anywhere  it can be brought into any country. Learn what you can do at www.endpolio.org.  On Voice of America  Sever talks about how #Rotary  UNICEF  CDC  the World Health Organization (WHO)  the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation  and governments work to fight polio.

In the 1950s  ELVIS PRESLEY supported the efforts of the March of Dimes to help end #polio.  You can be like Elvis and help End Polio Now!  For the past 25 years  #Rotary has been fighting to eradicate this crippling disease. Learn more and join the fight at www.endpolio.org.

When you take our free webinar on 12 September  you'll learn how you can help eradicate #polio as well as get ideas about how to celebrate World Polio Day  24 October. The webinar will be held 10 a.m. Central Time (Chicago) Register now at http://ow.ly/onIWr!

Facebook has become a powerful tool for sharing the message of #Rotary -- especially when used to its full potential.   Rotarian Erin Wagner  owner of a marketing firm specializing in social media marketing  shares what she's has learned about using Facebook to promote Rotary's good works. What are some of your tips?

Through #Rotary  we take action in communities through service projects. In part one of our free webinar series about the lifecycle of service projects  find out about the stages of a project and the importance of each of them.  Register and learn more at www.rotary.org/webinars.

The road to peace in Northern Ireland has been a long and difficult one. But progress has been made  and members of #Rotary recently came together in Derry-Londonderry to celebrate gains and commit to pushing forward. In an especially moving performance  participants heard witnesses of the conflict tell their own stories.   Read more in a Rotary Voices blog post from Rotary Peace Fellow Enda Young.

India hasn't reported a new polio case since January 2011  but polio's toll is still felt there. Rotarians in India are supporting a hospital ward for #polio survivors. The hospital offers surgeries to help people walk and regain independence. At www.endpolio.org  help #Rotary end polio.

The new www.rotary.org is live. See how #Rotary can help you join leaders  exchange ideas  and take action!  Thank you to all the Rotarians and family of Rotary who gave us feedback about what you would like to see on the website. #MyRotary
On the new rotary.org  you can find people who share your interests and you can read about #Rotary projects.
It's Membership and Extension Month at #Rotary. How has your Rotary club helped you connect for good?

When Rotarians and the family and friends of Rotary come together to commit to a cause  such as our PolioPlus initiative  the magnitude of our impact is clear. Use rotary.org and social media to help tell the #Rotary story.
The new rotary.org website can be a resource for getting involved in #Rotary and developing leadership skills and knowledge.
Together at #Rotary  we empower youth  improve health  promote peace  and advance our communities in all corners of the globe. Through the new rotary.org  you'll be able to explore Rotary grants.

#Rotary is all about building lifelong friendships -- connecting with fellow Rotarians across communities  cities  countries  and cultures. Our annual convention is one place where this happens. Join us for our 2014 RI Convention in Sydney  Australia  from 1 to 4 June.

On 26 August  rotary.org will have a new look and several added features. Read the blog #Rotary Digital at http://digital.rotary.org  to learn how you can join groups on #MyRotary to broaden Rotary's impact and much more! #RISocial
#Rotary brings together people like you -- leaders from all cultures and occupations who want to use their distinct expertise for good. The new website will help us do more together.
With 1.2 million members of #Rotary worldwide  our global community's impact has never been greater – and it continues to grow. The new website will help show that impact.
On the new rotary.org  learn about #Rotary grants and service projects.
What do you want people to know about #Rotary club meetings? What are some of your club's positive qualities?   Share it on social media to let people know more about Rotary's story.
People join #Rotary to give back to their communities and to connect with like-minded leaders and friends. The new rotary.org will help Rotarians do more.
Get ready for the new rotary.org!

Rotary approved a US$500 000 Rapid Response grant to address a recent polio outbreak in Somalia  which occurred in an area where a large number of children haven't been vaccinated against #polio.   The #Rotary grant to the World Health Organization (WHO) will cover operational costs -- including human resources  training  and transportation of health workers -- during August immunization activities aimed at reaching children younger than 10.  Read more at http://www.endpolio.org/news/2013/08/08/rotary-approves-$500-000-emergency-grant-for-somalia

An incubator that kept hundreds of newborn babies alive in Canada is now helping children in Chile  thanks to the efforts of Vancouver-area Rotarians.   We take action to improve communities! Read more about the donation of surplus medical supplies in Rotarian Chris Offer’s blog post!  #Rotary  http://blog.rotary.org/2013/08/12/offer/
Rotary International 2014-15 President-elect Gary C.K. Huang in Nigeria immunizing children against polio.

Rotarian Amelie Zegmout  from the United Arab Emirates  is climbing Mont Blanc  the highest peak in the Alps  to support the work of the World Food Programme (WFP) as her act of giving during Ramadan. It's one example of how we take action for positive change and work with other organizations to increase our impact.   Read more about Amelie on the #Rotary Voices blog.

Rotarians can take action and help more communities worldwide when their #Rotary clubs are thriving.   Rotarians  share our infographic about how regional membership plans can take advantage unique membership needs. Read more at http://ow.ly/nIscR

K.R. (Ravi) Ravindran  of the Rotary Club of Colombo  Western Province  Sri Lanka  is the selection of the Nominating Committee for President of Rotary International in 2015-16. Ravindran will become the president-nominee on 1 October if there are no challenging candidates.   Ravindran's top priority for #Rotary will be to increase membership. Also  it's important for Rotarians to speak with a consistent voice and share their stories  especially through social media  so others can see the impact Rotary has had in their lives  he said.

Thanks to the British government  more than 6 million people will be vaccinated against an outbreak of #polio in Somalia and Kenya  announced International Development Secretary Justine Greening.   The UK will provide about US$15. 3 million to allow the World Health Organization (WHO) to continue a vital vaccination campaign to tackle the first outbreak in Somalia since 2007. As of 31 July  there were 105 recorded cases in Somalia and Kenya.  Learn how you can help end this crippling disease at www.endpolio.org.  #rotary

Get the message out that Rotary connects leaders to exchange ideas and take action in communities. Join leaders at a #Rotary club near you.  Share this message on your social networks and end Membership and Extension Month in August with a Thunderclap! Sign up at http://thndr.it/18DOhuw for Twitter and Facebook  and you’ll join others in automatically sending out our Rotary message on 31 August at noon (Chicago time).

There's no need for you to travel this year if you want to Ride to End Polio in El Tour de Tucson in Arizona. From 18 to 23 November  you can participate from your stationary bike.  Last year  Rotary General Secretary John Hewko 111 miles in the ride  and together all riders raised enough money to purchase more than 1 million doses of #polio vaccine.  Sign up at http://ridetoendpolio.org/. Find out how Rotary is working to eradicate #polio at www.endpolio.org.  #Rotary

August is Membership and Extension Month at #Rotary. Rotarians  share this graphic to let your friends on social media -- and elsewhere -- know that you're a Rotarian and how #Rotary takes action in the community.  Friends of Rotary  why not ask a Rotarian about their club and how you can join?

A snapshot of #Rotary in 1912: Five clubs were chartered 1 August 1912  bringing the number of clubs worldwide to 50. The clubs were Washington  D.C.  USA; Dayton  Ohio  USA; Baltimore  Maryland  USA; Newark  New Jersey  USA; and London  England.  Learn more about Rotary's history at www.rotary.org/en/AboutUs/History/historic_moments/Pages/ridefault.aspx

Since 1947  Rotarians have provided scholarships to exceptional people who have had careers that make a difference.   Learn more at www.rotary.org/en/StudentsAndYouth/EducationalPrograms/Pages/ridefault.aspx.  #Rotary

For more than 25 years Rotarians have been fighting to eradicate polio because of stories such as the ones from Ontario  Canada  including the story one person shared about his mother after she was paralyzed by #polio  placed in an iron lung  and then used a rubber-tipped stick clenched between her teeth to turn the pages of a book.   You can learn more about our fight at www.endpolio.org. #Rotary

Interact  Rotary's program for young people ages 12 to 18  ignites a passion for service. During the recent #Rotary convention in Lisbon  Rotarians stopped by a booth to share their Interact stories and display sticky notes on a special timeline.   Read more about the inspiring stories they shared in Adam Arents' blog post for Rotary Voices.  http://blog.rotary.org/2013/07/29/interactbooth/

Find out more about Rotary's worldwide reach by following the #Rotary International president at www.facebook.com/RotaryPresident or the Rotary general secretary at www.facebook.com/johnhewko or https://twitter.com/johnhewko.

There have been no reported cases of wild poliovirus type 3 (WPV3) -- one of the two remaining strains of polio -- in any country this year. Last year  there were 15 WPV3 cases by this time.  We have been fighting to make history and eradicate polio for more than 25 years. Learn more and help end #polio at www.endpolio.org. #Rotary

Motivated by her fond memories of taking part in a Rotary Youth Exchange  Misha Garafalo has created a "Passport to Rotary" for her fellow club members to fill with "visa" stamps for their service activities.   Learn more about her idea in her blog post for #Rotary Voices.

Since 1988  the world has seen the number of #polio cases drop from 350 000 a year to less than 250 in 2012.  It's not easy to eradicate the second human disease in history  but it can be done. At http://ow.ly/njtez  read why Dr. Waqar Ajmal  of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation  believes we can eradicate this crippling disease.

The last smallpox survivor and a Somali #polio eradication champion  Ali Maow Maalin  passed away recently.   Smallpox is the first human disease to be eradicated  which Maalin got by not getting vaccinated. He then committed much of his time to trying to make polio the second human disease eradicated.  Read Rotarian George Camp’s blog post about Maalin on our blog  #Rotary Voices: http://blog.rotary.org/2013/07/18/somalia/
An incredible photo gallery in The New York Times that shows the story of #polio eradication  how #Rotary plays a role  and the courage of the vaccinators in Pakistan.

Rotarians … work in places that terrify government officials  said a The New York Times article at http://ow.ly/nchrU about the fight to end #polio in Pakistan. Despite challenges  Rotarians work on convincing parent to immunize children by using "love and affection." #Rotary

Canadian Rotarians raised more than US$200 000 for the PolioPlus campaign during a special bash for Dr. Robert Scott  whose tireless efforts have helped keep #polio eradication at the forefront of public awareness.   Read more about the special evening  which also celebrated Scott's 80th birthday  on #Rotary Voices.

The #polio outbreak in Somalia is a reminder of how we need to continue pressing on for polio eradication. Rotarian George Camp found inspiration recently in the story of Somalian Ali Maow Maalin  the last person stricken with naturally occurring smallpox and a diligent worker in the effort to rid his country of polio.   Read more of Camp's blog post about Maalin on #Rotary Voices.  http://blog.rotary.org/2013/07/18/somalia/

It's Nelson Mandela’s birthday 18 July and Mandela Day! Thank you Nelson Mandela for all you've given the world and for your support of #polio eradication.  "Polio respects no borders  and that as long as one child suffers  all children are at risk " said Mandela.  In 1997  he received the #Rotary Award for World Understanding  which was the highest Rotary honor then. In this photo from 1996  Mandela is immunizing a child at a "Kick Polio Out of Africa" event.   Learn more about our fight to end polio at www.endpolio.org.

You can join #Rotary and Brazilian Victoria's Secret model Isabeli Fontana in the World's Biggest Commercial at http://thisclose.endpolio.org/en/submissions/camera. Let the world know that after more than 25 years of working to make sure that no child is ever crippled again by polio  we're "This Close" to ending #polio.

Dr. Robert Scott  a past Rotary Foundation trustee chair  works tirelessly to fight polio. He often travels to the three polio-endemic countries of Afghanistan  Nigeria  and Pakistan to convince people to inoculate children for a safer  healthier life.   For Dr. Scott's birthday and to honor his work  his Rotary club in Cobourg  Ontario  Canada  raised more than $200 000 to help #Rotary End Polio Now. What a wonderful way for a Rotarian to celebrate a birthday!  Learn more about contributing to The Rotary Foundation at www.rotary.org/contribute.

There are 10 million people saved from paralysis because of #polio eradication efforts. Read the United Nations Foundation “Five reasons to care about polio” at www.unfoundation.org/blog/5-reasons-to-care-about-polio.html

From helping others to meeting a variety of community members  a 30-year-old Rotarian talks about in a Miami Herald (USA) article how the values of Rotary got him interested in joining and how his club is adjusting to attract new members.

Recent devastating floods throughout the northern state of Uttarakhand  India  displaced thousands of local residents and many died.  Thank you to all those who helped  such as Rotarian Dr. Nischal Pandey who led a medical relief team to assist flood victims.    Learn how you can help at www.rotary.org/en/ServiceAndFellowship/collaborate/Announcements/Pages/130703_annc_indiaflooding.aspx?fb
A new Rotary year started 1 July and with it came some changes  including new Rotary grants and allowing for more Rotary e-clubs. Read about what's new and let us know what you think.

Watch a profile of RI President Ron Burton  as he begins his year of encouraging Rotarians to Engage Rotary  Change Lives. “It’s a real challenging theme  I call it an action theme. It is going to require you to do something ” says Burton. “Rolling up your sleeves to pass out pancakes ... or any of the other kinds of hands-on projects are really what creates the fellowship that makes Rotary extremely worthwhile.”

A New Rotary year has begun. The Rotary Foundation’s new grant model  Future Vision  has launched for all districts  and a number of changes enacted by the Council on Legislation are in effect. Also  new leaders are in place at club  district  and international levels. Read about all the changes you should know to make the most of this Rotary year  and Engage Rotary  Change Lives. http://www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/130701_news_newyear.aspx
RI President Ron Burton invites Rotarians to find the magic of Rotary and Engage Rotary  Change Lives. Read the president's blog post on Rotary Voices. http://blog.rotary.org/2013/07/01/burton/
The new Rotary year starts 1 July. What projects will your club be working on in 2013-14?

As the 2013 RI Convention in Lisbon comes to a close  President-elect Ron Burton urges Rotarians to remember "what a gift we have in Rotary."  See more videos from this year's convention in Lisbon at http://www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/130623_IC13_videos.aspx

At our convention  Emmy-winning actress and This Close polio ambassador Archie Panjabi talked about why she supports polio; Dr. Bruce Aylward  World Health Organization (WHO) assistant director-general for polio emergencies and country collaboration  gave the latest news on our fight to end polio; and Rotarian John Germ  vice chair of the International PolioPlus Committee announced that the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will match two-to-one  up to US$35 million per year  every dollar Rotary commits to reduce the funding shortfall for #polio eradication through 2018.   See more videos from the 2013 RI Convention in Lisbon at http://www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/130623_IC13_videos.aspx

We're accepting the challenge to make Rotary better by doing larger projects with greater impact  said Past RI President Wilf Wilkinson  talking about Future Vision and Rotary grants  which officially launches 1 July.  Watch the video to learn more about what happened at Rotary convention (#ricon13) in Lisbon. Listen to Mirna Edelmira Perez Garcia  director of the Centro Educativo de Ninas from Guatemala  talk about the children who benefited from a Rotary grant.

Future Vision  now Rotary grants  will help us do more good in the world. See the Future Vision video shown in our convention (#ricon13) plenary. Get ready to do more good in the world when the new grants officially begin 1 July.

During the convention  Rotarians were urged to step forward and make a difference from peace activists Emmanuel Jal and 2011 Nobel Peace Laureate Leymah Gbowee.  Read more at www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/130625_news_plentwo.aspx
Great news from our convention in Lisbon (#ricon13)

Thank you Sir Emeka Offor for giving an additional US$1 million to The Rotary Foundation for #polio eradication.  Offer made the announcement during a Rotary convention (#ricon13) workshop. He said  as a Rotarian  he takes pride in the good work #Rotary is doing and is pleased with Rotary's leadership in the campaign to end polio.   Learn how you can help end polio at www.endpolio.org.

There are hundreds of booths in the RI Convention's House of Friendship  such as the Literacy Rotarian Action Group booth. Find out how to join  learn about literacy projects  and exchange literacy-related information.   What has been one of your favorite booths at the Rotary convention in Lisbon (#ricon13) so far?
Couldn't join 20 000 Rotarians at the convention in Lisbon? See what you missed on the convention’s first day.   Follow us on social media at #ricon13.

If you're at the RI Convention in Lisbon (#ricon13)  share what you love about Rotary conventions or some of your favorite things to do in and around Lisbon (for example  restaurants or shopping spots).  You also can post about it on LinkedIn at http://ow.ly/miG2J
You can feel the energy of Rotary during the RI Convention 23-26 June in Lisbon. Join us on Facebook and Twitter with #ricon13 for inspiration and an exchange of ideas from around the world.

Volunteers are the heart of Rotaract! Rotaractors from around the world are meeting for the 2013 Rotaract Preconvention Meeting in Lisbon  21-22 June. Follow what happening with #rotaract13 and #ricon13.  Learn more about the convention at www.riconvention.org
Do you have a vision for a better world? So does The Rotary Foundation! You can help at www.rotary.org/contribute.

If you see one of our "This Close" to ending polio ads  signs  and posters around Lisbon – such as this one -- take a picture next to one while you're also making the "This Close" symbol.   Show us your "This Close" photo at the PolioPlus booth in the House of Friendship  Pavilion 2  from 23 to 26 June  at the RI Convention #ricon13 for a chance to win an End Polio Now prize  which could be an autographed item from a celebrity "This Close" ambassador. (The person receiving this prize will be randomly selected.)   Challenge your friends to see who can get the most "This Close" photos  and share the photos through your social media now to let them know that we're "This Close" to ending polio.

Join us in Lisbon 23-26 June for the RI Convention! Just as the first Rotarians did 100 years ago  exchange ideas with people from around the world.  Connect with us on social media during convention using #ricon13. Read more about how you can experience the convention at www.rotary.org/en/Members/Events/Announcements/Pages/13may23_annc_conv_sm.aspx?fb
Happy Father's Day to all of our Rotary dads!  Learn more about the "father" of Rotary  Paul Harris  who started this organization in 1905.

At Próximos Pasos school for girls in Guatemala  Rotarians have helped give the students clean water and proper nutrition  and the results are apparent. The girls are able to focus on their studies  and they're enthusiastic about education.   About the project  "You have to involve as many Rotarians as you can  locally and internationally " says Jorge Aufranc  of the Rotary Club of Guatemala Sur.  Read more at www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/130607_news_guatemala.aspx?fb
Be an assignment editor  and vote for CNN to cover polio eradication!  Vote at www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/opinion/change-the-list

Made possible by you – the ones who share our messages and donate to The Rotary Foundation -- projects that teach people to read  provide clean water  create a more peaceful world  protect mothers and children  and so much more.  Share our video highlighting our Foundation or give online at www.rotary.org/contribute.
Help Rotary make sustainable  life-changing projects in your community and around the world. Every contribution truly makes a difference. Contribute today at www.rotary.org/contribute.

The first Rotary club in Russia was chartered in Moscow on 5 June 1990. This photo shows 1989-90 RI President Hugh Archer in Red Square during one of his trips to establish Rotary in Russia.  When was the first club in your country chartered?

With continued effort  stopping polio transmission by the end of 2014 is a realistic prospect  says a new report. Read more at http://ow.ly/lMWsg  "We’re working to ensure that the poliovirus will be found only in history books and not in children " says Rotary's International PolioPlus Committee Chair Robert Scott.

Photographer Jean-Marc Giboux has traveled the world to document the brave men and women who put their lives on the line to fight polio.  You can help fight polio and give to The Rotary Foundation at www.rotary.org/contribute
Rotarians are asking for a little R-E-S-P-E-C-T and awareness about our work to End Polio Now.   Learn how you can help end this crippling disease at www.endpolio.org.
Why should someone in their 20s join Rotary? To meet people and to give back to the community  says Rotarian Drew Kessler in Newsday. How would you answer that question?

We're one of the world's most followed nonprofits on social media  according to this infographic from BigMarker.com. We couldn't do it without all of our followers on Facebook and Twitter (@rotary). Thank you for being part of the Rotary story!   Please share this and other Rotary stories on social media to help spread awareness about the positive changes we help create in our communities.

Without water  we’ll never have conflict resolution. Without water  we’ll never have basic education and literacy  says Rotarian Ron Denham.  Join him and other Rotarians interested in water and sanitation projects at the World Water Summit  in Lisbon  Portugal  21 June.   Read more at www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/TheRotarian/Pages/Denham1306.aspx?fb

Rotarians take action and make positive changes in communities. For example  in Liberia -- which after a devastating civil war lacks youth facilities -- the Rotary Club of Sinkor - Liberia broke ground on a center for young people in a suburb of Monrovia.   Read more about the work of Rotarians on www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/TheRotarian/Pages/130501_news_roundup.aspx?fb

Thank you  Australia! Its government will provide $80 million from 2015 to 2018 to help finish the job and achieve worldwide polio eradication.  It was Australia's Sir Clem Renouf who  as president of Rotary International in 1978 and 1979  led the international campaign to vaccinate every child against polio. As a result of these early efforts by Rotary  the global community came together in 1988 to launch the Global Polio Eradication Initiative.  Learn more about Rotary's fight to end polio at www.endpolio.org.

The competition is on! Spain has taken the lead for the most photos in our World Biggest Commercial. They’re followed by Portugal and then the United States.  Help raise awareness about our fight to eradicate polio and end this crippling disease. Upload your photo and be a part of the World’s Biggest Commercial.

Eradicating polio matters is because it's a disease without a cure  but it's 100 percent preventable. If we don’t finish the job of eradicating polio  the World Health Organization predicts polio could resurge and cause upwards of 200 000 cases during the next 10 years.   Experts predict US$40 billion to $50 billion in savings through 2035  if we can eradicate the disease.  Read more from John Salyers  who serves on Rotary's Polio Eradication Advocacy Task Force. http://www.kentucky.com/2013/05/19/2645479/ky-voices-polio-still-a-scourge.html

Peace is not something that can only be achieved through treaties  by governments  or through heroic struggles. It is something that we can find  and that we can achieve -- every day  and in many simple ways  said Rotary International President Sakuji Tanaka at the last of three Rotary Global Peace Forums.

Rotarians make a difference in their community and globally  including through water and sanitation projects. You can help support that work through our Foundation at www.rotary.org/contribute.  If you're in Lisbon  Portugal  on 21 June join us at the World Water Summit  where you can learn about making water projects sustainable as well as meet other people from around the world who are also working on water and sanitation projects. Read more at www.startwithwater.org.

Rotary lost a strong voice for polio eradication in Pakistan.   Abdul Waheed Khan  who headed the Site Town Polio Resource Center in Karachi  Sindh  Pakistan  died tragically in an attack on 13 May that also wounded his daughter and brother. International PolioPlus Committee Chair Robert S. Scott remembers Khan in a blog post on Rotary Voices.
Congratulations to Nan McCreadie!

A case of type 1 polio has been reported in the Banadir region of Somalia. The country's first case since March 2007. Genetic sequencing suggests that the virus is closely related to a type 1 virus strain circulating in Nigeria  which is still a polio-endemic country.  Polio must be eradicated everywhere to make all the world's children safe. So in response to the outbreak  an immunization campaign is taking place 14-16 May  aimed at reaching more than 350 000 children in the Banadir region.  Learn more how you can support our efforts to end polio now at www.endpolio.org.

Interested in working in the field of peace and conflict resolution? Then you may want to be a Rotary Peace Fellow.   Answering all your questions on Facebook -- especially about the application process -- will be Rotary staff  alum Mark Flanigan  and current Peace Fellow Rhett Sangster. They’ll be in a Facebook chat on www.facebook.com/rotarycenters 15 May from 2 to 3 p.m. Central Time (Chicago).  Learn more about this Facebook event at  https://www.facebook.com/events/541900462514973/
Happy Mother's Day! See how Rotary is making a difference in the area of maternal and child health.
Rotary International 2012-13 President Sakuji Tanaka says peace has many meanings. What does peace mean to you?  Read his May message at http://ow.ly/kKkW8

Are you a Rotarian with a great "connection" story? Were you just one person who wanted to do good but couldn’t do it alone?   We're looking for stories about people who joined a Rotary club and made connections with other Rotarians to accomplish something bigger than themselves.   If you're a Rotarian with one of these stories  we'd love to hear about it! Respond here on Facebook or email RotaryYPC@rotary.org.

Congratulations to The Rotarian magazine staff for an outstanding cover! Their March 2012 issue beat out Time and New York magazines for having the best magazine cover in the "Service" category in the ASME Best Cover Contest. They also were finalists in the "Most delicious" category.

Way to go Rotarians! "The Harper Government congratulates Canadians and Rotarians for their impressive fundraising achievements aimed at ending polio once and for all " said Canada's Minister of International Cooperation Julian Fantino.  Anyone can advocate for ending polio at www.endpolio.org.

Rotary Foundation Trustee Chair Wilfrid J. Wilkinson met with Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan to discuss the government's and Rotary's support for polio eradication. Wilkinson also met with the Nigeria National PolioPlus Committee  which is playing a key role in the country's fight to become polio free.  Learn how you can be an advocate in the polio eradication effort at www.endpolio.org.
Let's End Polio Now!

In Forbes  Rotarian Devin Thorpe talks with Rotarians and found what they have in common – they were working for the common good on all levels.  We love the article and welcome to Rotary!  For those who want to learn more about how to join  visit www.rotary.org/join.
Thank you to those who made these pledges possible  including all the Rotarians who have diligently worked for more than 25 years to end polio.
Share the graphic and help raise awareness this week  which is World Immunization Week  about the need to end polio.

It's National Volunteer Week. Thank you to all of our volunteers for making a difference in their communities and for following us on social media!  You can learn more about how to join us at www.rotary.org/join.
Happy Earth Day!

Paul Harris was born 19 April 1868 in Racine  Wisconsin  USA. He moved to Chicago in 1896 and founded the first Rotary club in 1905.   In recognition of Harris's birthday  help us do good in the world by making a contribution to The Rotary Foundation at www.rotary.org/contribute.   Learn more about the founder of Rotary.

We're making progress in the fight to end polio. 18 April marks a year since the last case of type 3 polio was reported in Pakistan  which is one of three polio-endemic countries. The other countries are Afghanistan and Nigeria.  In 2012  there were only seven cases of type 3 polio reported globally. So far this year  no type 3 cases have been reported.
Learn how Rotaract clubs can become active again by just updating their contact information.

The impact of the work of Rotary and its partners on polio eradication "will be felt first by children and families who will no longer need to fear polio  but ultimately will go far beyond eradicating one disease."  Read more in the The Huffington Post from Ciro de Quadros  executive vice president of the Sabin Vaccine Institute  and share the article for World Immunization Week  which is next week.

Rotarians in Austin  Texas  have delivered solar-powered lights to schoolchildren in Belize  in partnership with the Grid Earth Project. The lights are less hazardous than kerosene lamps  and provide a longer  higher quality of reading light than candles  meaning children can study longer.   The project is just one way Rotary brings together people with diverse viewpoints to creatively tackle challenges. Read more about it and see a video on our blog  Rotary Voices.

Bill Gates wrote in the The Cairo Review that it will take funds  commitment  and resolve to End Polio Now. He also talked about the dedication of Rotarians in eradicating polio as well his own commitment.  "Ending polio is my top personal priority " said Gates.

Rotarians in Lagos  Nigeria  held their annual eye surgery camp to coincide with the West Africa Project Fair in October. Many of the patients had given up all hope of ever seeing again and were overjoyed that cataract surgery restored their sight.   On our blog  Rotary Voices  read about this inspiring event and how we're working for the common good.  You can help make a difference at www.rotary.org/contribute.
Our president talks about the meaning of Rotary.

How do you tell the story of Rotary?  "During my years in Rotary  I have witnessed over and over again how communities and individuals benefit because of Rotary activities " said Rotary Foundation Trustee Chair Wilfrid Wilkinson in his monthly message. "We owe it to our community and the world to tell our story  to make the world aware of our efforts."  You can share his message in your Rotary publications: www.rotary.org/en/AboutUs/RotaryLeadership/TrusteeChair/Pages/Messages.aspx?fb

Come join us in Lisbon  Portugal  for the 2013 RI Convention  23-26 June. You’ll get inspired and exchange ideas with leaders from around the world. You also can talk about the convention on Twitter with #ricon13.  Register by 31 March at www.riconvention.org  to take advantage of reduced prices.

Rotarians take action for the common good in many ways  from running health camps to flying a hot air balloon to raise awareness about polio eradication.  Read more about how we persevere to help in communities worldwide.

In countries around the world  Rotarians use their expertise to help communities. Rotary International 2012-13 President Sakuji Tanaka visited a medical mission supported by Rotarians in India and Taiwan that gave hundreds of people in India free medical and dental screenings in 10 days. Great job  Rotarians!

Rotarians in Chico  California  USA  partnered with the Rotary clubs of Moshi and Mwika  Tanzania  to provide community development  clean water  and better sanitation for hundreds of villagers in the region around Mt. Kilimanjaro.   Through their five-year partnership  the clubs have learned many lessons. One of the most important  says Chico Rotarian Walt Schafer  is the need for local villagers to assume ownership and responsibility for a project  so it will keep going for the long haul.   Schafer blogs about the collaboration on Rotary Voices.
See how we take action for the common good. Visit us on www.pinterest.com/rotary and http://instagram.com/rotaryinternational.   Share the images on your social media and publications.
World Water Day is 22 March. On our official LinkedIn group  Rotarians talk about some of their water projects. http://ow.ly/jiFyu  Join us in helping communities!

Every 20 seconds  a child dies from a water-related illness  and 3.4 million people die each year from a water-related disease.  On UN-Water World Water Day  22 March  you can make a difference by sharing on social media the work of Rotary and others in the area of clean water and sanitation.  Read about how we're taking action at www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/130321_news_waterlessons.aspx

We make a difference in our communities and globally. It’s Literacy Month. Share this graphic to help raise awareness about our work.  You can contribute to the work of Rotary at www.rotary.org/contribute

It's the UN's first International Day of Happiness. Share on social media how Rotary makes you happy or you've used Rotary to make others happy.  "When we contribute to the common good  we ourselves are enriched " said Ban Ki-moon  the U.N. Secretary-General. He marked the day by calling for a reinforced commitment to inclusive and sustainable human development.  Read more at http://rendezvous.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/20/happy-international-happiness-day/

Rotary empowers youth. As a 16-year-old  Danae Cooney went to Fiji and took part in a service project with her Rotarian stepfather to refurbish a rotting unusable preschool. The New Zealand teen experienced the life-changing potential of service  "cementing my dream of making humanitarian work an ongoing part of my life."   Read more of Cooney's story and see images of her Fiji trip on our blog  Rotary Voices.

Thank you to Shot@Life  United Nations Foundation  and March of Dimes for joining us and Bill Gates to support ending polio. Rotary's efforts have prevented more than 5 million children worldwide from getting polio.
A message from Rotary International 2012-13 President Sakuji Tanaka about youth and building peace.

Happy Rotaract Week!  World Rotaract Week  11-17 March  commemorates the 1968 chartering of the first club  in North Carolina  USA.   During the week  Rotaract clubs are asked to partner with their sponsor Rotary clubs on a service project and to encourage a nearby Rotary club to sponsor a new Rotaract club in the area. Also  members of the Rotaract and sponsor clubs are encouraged to attend each other's meetings.

About 800 people in Thailand now have safe drinking water because of a Foundation global grant and Rotarians.  To ensure that the project is sustainable  a four-person team from Thailand was trained on pipeline construction as well as sanitization and small water system management

The Pakistan National PolioPlus Committee paid tribute on 24 February in Peshawar to health workers who were killed while serving in the country’s polio eradication effort. The committee also paid tribute on 6 February to health workers in Karachi who lost their lives during similar attacks. At both events  the Rotarians and the provincial health minister presented compensation to the victims' family members.  Rotary International has joined the government of Pakistan and our partners in the Global Polio Eradication Initiative in condemning the attacks and extending our deepest sympathy to the families of the victims.  Learn more about our work to eradicate polio at www.endpolio.org.

It's Literacy Month. Share this graphic to help raise awareness that Rotarians work on basic education and literacy projects.  Help support literacy projects through The Rotary Foundation at www.rotary.org/contribute

Rotary coordinators and Rotary public image coordinators  including RPIC Denise Vieira S. Goncalves from Zone 22/23A  put service in action during a training event in Chicago. The coordinators formed teams to bag 16 000 packages for a chapter of Kids Against Hunger Coalition  sponsored by four Rotary clubs in Rock County  Wisconsin.   Volunteers packaged meals containing rice  soy  dehydrated vegetables  and 21 vitamins and minerals.   Read more about how coordinators support Rotarians at www.rotary.org/en/members/runningadistrict/publicimagecoordinators/pages/ridefault.aspx

Rotarians from the UK talk about why they visit India to help immunize children against polio.  Rotary launched the global fight against polio in 1985 and since then has helped to immunize more than 2.5 billion children.

Rotary International 2012-13 President Sakuji Tanaka congratulated the members of the Rotary Club of Toronto for 100 years of outstanding Rotary service and for their generous contribution of US$100 000 to the polio eradication campaign. The Canadian International Development Agency and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation matched their contribution  bringing the total to $300 000. Thank you all very much for your tremendous efforts.

In eradicating polio from Nigeria and Pakistan and Afghanistan  we'll be protecting children into the future  but also building networks of cooperation toward a more peaceful  tolerant and productive future  says Rotarian Charles Cogan in an op-ed in the StarTribune.

A grant from The Rotary Foundation will help Rotarians and a team of experts bring clean water to more than 1 800 people in the Thane district of India.  Contribute to more projects like this at www.rotary.org/contribute

Happy 90th anniversary to Rotarians in Rio de Janeiro  Brazil! The first Rotary club in Brazil was chartered there on 28 February 1923. In the photo below are participants at the 1948 RI Convention in Rio de Janeiro.  For more than a century  Rotarians have gathered at their annual convention to exchange great ideas and connect with old and new friends.   Register by 31 March for your last chance to take advantage of reduced registration prices for the 2013 convention in Lisbon at www.riconvention.org.

Thank you New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg! He's donating US$100 million to support polio eradication. Rotary launched a global fight to end polio in 1985.   Mayor Bloomberg said  "We're at a critical juncture in the global effort to end polio. If we're going to achieve a polio-free world  we must act quickly and commit now to providing the resources needed."  Learn how you can join the mayor and others in ending polio at www.endpolio.org.

Rotarians around the world celebrated Rotary's 108th anniversary  23 February  with a variety of events ranging from global swimming marathons to the illumination of landmark buildings with the End Polio Now message. See a slideshow of images from this year's celebration on our blog  Rotary Voices http://blog.rotary.org/2013/02/26/anniversary/. You also can send us photos of your own celebration at blog@rotary.org.  The Karachi Municipal Corporation (KMC) building was one of many historic buildings lit up for Rotary's 108th anniversary.
Congratulations to the Rotary Club of Toronto for 100 years of humanitarian service!

Celebrate 108 years of Rotary on our anniversary  23 February. Join the World's Biggest Commercial and help raise awareness about our fight to eradicate polio.   Learn more how to end polio at www.endpolio.org.

We're 108 years old on 23 February  and we're celebrating more than a century of positive change!   Share on social media what Rotary means to you. You also can share this graphic to help raise awareness about the work of Rotary.
Share the work of Rotary for our 108th anniversary (#ri108)  23 February.
Thanks David Beckham for joining Rotary and its partners in fighting polio!

As Rotary gets ready to celebrate its 108th year on 23 February  we're also celebrating some important gains in ending polio.  Worldwide  222 polio cases were reported in 2012  a little more than one-third of the 650 cases reported in 2011.   India marked its second year without polio on 13 January. Overall  the annual incidence of polio has decreased more than 99 percent since 1988  when polio infected about 350 000 children per year.   Learn how you can use advocacy to help us End Polio Now.  Read more at www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/130221_news_advocacy.aspx

Through The Rotary Foundation  Rotarians helped thousands of families in Peru get clean water.  For our 108th anniversary on 23 February (#ri108)  we're honoring the work of Rotarians for the past 108 years.  Help contribute to that work by donating to The Rotary Foundation at www.rotary.org/contribute.

Let your social media friends know about the work of Rotary by telling them what Rotary means to you or sharing a graphic.  You can learn more how you can support our polio eradication work at www.endpolionow.org.

About 1 billion children under the age of 18 live in areas affected by conflict. But world peace means more than ending wars: It also means safety for everyone  including society's most vulnerable members.   Peace and conflict resolution is a Rotary area of focus. For our 108th anniversary on 23 February (#ri108)  we're featuring the humanitarian work of Rotary.   Contribute to our work at www.rotary.org/contribute.

Winter can be brutal  especially without a proper coat. Through Operation Warm  Inc. and with the help of social media  last year Rotarians in more than 90 clubs made a difference by giving more than 17 000 children winter coats. In the past five years  Rotary clubs have provided more than 75 000 children with warm winter coats. Way to go  Rotarians!  Learn more about how to get the most from social media at www.rotaryleader-en.org/rotaryleader-en/en201301#pg4.  Share how you've used social media to make a difference.

Rotary turns 108 on 23 February. Celebrate by keeping Rotary strong. On social media  tell your friends and family how Rotary makes a difference and what Rotary means to you. On Twitter  you can use #ri108  and you also can participate in today’s Twitter history quiz with that hash tag.   Share this graphic on social media. Basic education and literacy is a Rotary area of focus. Has your club worked on an education or literacy project?

This week we're celebrating 108 years of humanitarian service. Tell us how Rotary has impacted your life here or on Twitter with the hash tag #ri108. Or celebrate by donating US$108 to The Rotary Foundation at www.rotary.org/contribute?fb.  See how the Foundation is making a difference.

Rotary’s 108th anniversary will be a 23 February (#ri108). Share a few of our historic moments on video  including Rotary founder Paul Harris planting a tree and at his home  Rotary clubs in India  and Rotary’s first efforts eradicating polio.

We’ll be 108 years old on 23 February  and we're celebrating the event all next week.  Help celebrate our years of Service Above Self by sharing with your friends and family on social media what Rotary means to you. On Twitter  use the hash tag #ri108.

Why are we still talking about polio? Shot@Life shared the story of polio survivor and Rotarian Ann Lee Hussey. Survivors such as Ann Lee and for their fight to prevent another child from getting polio is why we're still talking about this disease.

Through advocacy  you can use your networks to help fight polio.  For example  share this graphic on social media to help spread the word.  Learn more in Global Outlook  which is in the February issue of The Rotarian magazine.

Share these “5 Easy Ways to Improve the World” -- especially item 4  which is donating to Rotary to End Polio Now! For US$15  you can protect 25 children from polio and help eradicate this disease worldwide.  Thanks to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and Bill Gates  for recognizing our work  as well the work of some great other organizations  such as (RED)  UNICEF  IntraHealth International  and ONE.

Together Rotary and the world's largest postgraduate water education facility  UNESCO-IHE  are helping improve water sanitation worldwide.   Read about how Rotary is funding scholars in a blog post by Henk Jaap Kloosterman  Rotary Club of Voorburg-Vliet  The Netherlands  and district UNESCO-IHE coordinator.

In Rotary  we don't divide our work by nation or culture. What matters is Service Above Self  says Rotary International 2012-13 President Sakuji Tanaka. Peace and conflict resolution is one of our areas of focus. Help share the message in February during World Understanding Month.    You can support our Rotary Peace Centers by finding program candidates or contributing to the centers. Learn more at www.rotary.org/rotarycenters.

The work of Rotary was talked about worldwide in January. There were mentions of Rotary in TIME magazine  the The Wall Street Journal  the The New York Times  Discover Magazine  the Today Show  SET-TV in Taiwan  MBC and the Korean Herald in Korea.

This week Bill Gates has spread the message about the work of Rotary and its polio eradication partners -- the CDC  UNICEF  and the World Health Organization (WHO) -- in fighting polio.   He mentioned Rotary on the Today Show and the Dimbleby Lecture on BBC as well as in the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation annual letter.   It takes everyone to help End Polio Now. Let's join Bill Gates in spreading the message of our work in ending polio. Share this message on social media  websites  and club and district newsletters.

On the Today Show  Bill Gates spoke about his work in the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation to make the world a better place  including to End Polio Now. He recommends that people donate to The Rotary Foundation to make a difference  especially for ending polio: www.rotary.org/contribute or www.endpolio.org.

Rotary will be 108 years old on 23 February (#ri108). We'd like to hear from you about how your club or district is celebrating  and we may include it in an article on www.rotary.org.  Learn more about our history at www.rotary.org/history.

More than 1 800 Rotarians  Rotary alumni  and supporters of Rotary's peace program took part in the Rotary Global Peace Forum in Honolulu  Hawaii  25-27 January.   Peace and conflict is one of Rotary;s areas of focus. Test your Rotary peace knowledge during our #RotaryPeace quiz  which will be on Twitter @rotary from 1 to 2 p.m. Wednesday  30 January.  Read more at www.facebook.com/rotary/events.

On 1 July  The Rotary Foundation will launch its new grant model  the Future Vision Plan. The new grant model streamlines grants and will help promote Rotary as a leader in global development and humanitarian service.  Download a guide to the new Foundation grants at www.rotary.org/ridocuments/en_pdf/global_outlook_1211_en.pdf and share it with your club.

Harris died 27 January 1947 after a prolonged illness. He preferred contributions to The Rotary Foundation upon his death in lieu of flowers. As news of his death spread  Rotarians were encouraged to commemorate the founder of Rotary by contributing to the Foundation and supporting causes dear to his heart.  Learn more about Harris at www.rotary.org/en/AboutUs/History/paulharris/Pages/ridefault.aspx?fb.   Support the Foundation by making a contribution at www.rotary.org/contribute?fb.
Join the World's Biggest Commercial at http://thisclose.endpolio.org/en! Every photo helps save a child form polio  thanks to a US$50 000 donation from PhRMA.

Without Rotary  this polio campaign wouldn’t be anywhere  said Bill Gates.  Watch how Rotarians are leading the way to eradicating polio and how the strength of Rotary's voice is holding local authorities accountable for helping to End Polio Now.  Learn how you can make a difference at www.endpolio.org.

Registration deadline is 20 January for the Rotary Global Peace Forum Hawaii 2013 (#rotarypeace). Rotary International President Sakuji Tanaka will attend the event  which is from 25-27 January  to help inspire Rotarians and community leaders to bring Peace Through Service.  Learn more at www.peaceforumhawaii.com.
See RI President-elect Ron Burton announce the 2013-14 theme from the International Assembly on 14 January. Share the message with your club.
Share the 2013-14 Rotary theme from RI President-elect Ron Burton: “Engage Rotary  Change Lives.”

Today marks two years since the last case of polio in India. In this country -- where some said polio could never be eradicated -- thanks to millions of health workers  along with Rotarians  dedicated officials  community members  and parents -- the tide has turned against polio.   Together  we can end this crippling disease and End Polio Now. Help us change the world at www.endpolio.org.

For United's 10 Million Charity Miles Giveaway  we officially came in second place and will receive 2 501 338 charity miles from United.   Rotarians will use the miles for humanitarian missions  such as transporting sick children to hospitals and National Immunization Days for polio eradication. Thank you to all those who voted. You made a difference.  We congratulate the Shriners Hospitals for Children  who took first place.

A TIME article about the war on polio says of the crippling disease  "2013 could be the year in which the climactic battles are fought." We can End Polio Now!  Read more at http://healthland.time.com/2013/01/03/the-final-battle-against-polio/#ixzz2Gw9ytBio

See photos of Rotary putting Service Above Self in 2012  including this photo of Aseefa Bhutto Zardari  daughter of Pakistan's president  administering the polio vaccine.  View more photos at http://www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/121231_news_yearinreview.aspx?fb

A Rotary classic: Paul Harris  considered the founder of Rotary  filling a bird feeder at his home  Comely Bank  in Chicago  in December 1942.   Read how Paul Harris started Rotary to find fellowship: http://www.rotary.org/en/AboutUs/History/paulharris/Pages/ridefault.aspx?fb  Photo copyright Rotary International
Have a Happy New Year!
This is Rotary – and one of our most liked videos. We help change the world by providing networking opportunities and through our humanitarian service.  Support our work at www.rotary.org/contribute.

Thank you for all you do for Rotary and for putting Service Above Self. Learn more about how The Rotary Foundation supports the humanitarian projects of Rotarians and how you can help at  www.rotary.org/contribute?fb

Happy Holidays! Thank you for following us on Facebook and for all you that you do to put Service Above Self.  Today is also the last day to vote for Rotary at http://10millioncharitymiles.com/charity/39 in United's Charity Miles Giveaway. Rotarians use the airline miles to help change lives.
One of the favorite Rotary photos of 2012:  Rotarians formed a smiley face at the 2012 RI Convention in Bangkok.

Vote daily until 25 December  per device and browser  for Rotary in United's Charity Miles at http://10millioncharitymiles.com/charity/39 to help Rotarians get free airline miles to change lives. Share this post with your friends and family!  Rotarians can use Charity Miles for humanitarian projects  such as transporting children with birth defects to hospitals for treatments they can't receive at home and to go immunize children against polio.

For more than 25 years  the people of Pakistan have worked tirelessly to help eradicate polio from their country. Our thoughts and prayers are with those health workers who were killed and their families. We honor the contributions all those have made who worked for a better future for the children of Pakistan.   Read a statement from Rotary about the recent attacks against health workers in Pakistan: http://ow.ly/getLQ

Vote daily per device and browser at http://10millioncharitymiles.com/charity/39 until 25 December in United's Charity Miles Giveaway to help Rotarians get free airline miles.  Rotarians have used Charity Miles for humanitarian projects such as transporting children with birth defects to hospitals for treatments they wouldn’t otherwise receive and sending volunteers to help immunize children against polio.

The Rotary Club of Newtown  Connecticut  USA  established a Sandy Hook School fund. The fund is dedicated to the victims of the Sandy Hook School tragedy  their families and those in the Newtown community who have been affected  to help support both their short-term and long-term needs.  Our deepest condolences and sorrow for the Sandy Hook School tragedy.

Polio eradication in India has been named one of the top 10 health milestones of 2012! Read about Rotary International's role in fighting this crippling disease. http://psiimpact.com/india-celebrates-one-year-polio-free/
One in six people worldwide lack access to safe drinking water. Help us make a difference at http://www.rotary.org/contribute

This ceramic cup was presented to an outstanding Japanese Rotarian in the years before World War II. During the war  it was buried for safekeeping  and in 1953 it was given to RI General Secretary George R. Means as a token of gratitude for his efforts in the postwar reorganization of Rotary in Japan.   Read more at www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/121213_news_history.aspx?fb  Rotary Images/Monika Lozinska

Vote daily per device and browser at http://10millioncharitymiles.com/charity/39 until 25 December in United's Charity Miles Giveaway to help Rotarians get free airline miles to change lives.  In more than 34 000 clubs worldwide  Rotarians volunteer in communities at home and abroad to support education and job training  provide clean water  combat hunger  improve health and sanitation  and eradicate polio.

It only takes a few seconds to vote for Rotary in United's 10 Million Charity Miles Giveaway at http://10millioncharitymiles.com/charity/39. You can vote daily per device.  Rotarians use Charity Miles to change lives by helping with humanitarian projects  such as transporting children with birth defects to hospitals for treatments they can't receive at home.

Charity Miles were used to send volunteers to help immunize children against polio. Worldwide  Rotary has helped prevent more than 5 million children from getting polio  and our fight isn’t over.  Vote again this year for Rotary in United's 10 Million Charity Miles Giveaway so we can End Polio Now.  Vote daily  per device  until 25 December at http://10millioncharitymiles.com/charity/39

Thanks to your votes last year  United's Charity Miles have provided transportation for Rotary's Gift of Life surgical teams  which traveled to Haiti and El Salvador so volunteer doctors and nurses could perform life-saving heart surgery for children and train local doctors.   We're asking for your vote again this year so we can keep making a difference in the world. Vote daily  per device  until 25 December at http://10millioncharitymiles.com/charity/39.

Help Rotary get free airline miles for humanitarian projects. Vote once a day per device (such as laptop or tablet) until 25 December  in United's 10 Million Charity Miles Giveaway.  Last year  we came in second place. Let's go for first this year! Vote at http://10millioncharitymiles.com/
We're only a few hundred likes away from 200 000! Share this photo  and ask your Facebook friends to like Rotary International's Facebook page. Let people know about the humanitarian work of Rotary!

What could be more creative than holding a polio immunization camp at a zoo? That’s what Rotarians and Rotaractors in Lahore Green City  Punjab  Pakistan did recently. More than 500 children were vaccinated in front of the elephant compound at the Lahore Zoo. “Parents appreciated the novel idea  and the club has decided to have frequent camps there to cover the maximum children from various areas and of all classes ” says Khaula Shaheen Inam  president of the Rotary Club of Lahore Green City. See photos of the club’s most recent activities on its Facebook page:  https://www.facebook.com/RotaryClubofLahoreGreenCity

On 20 November  Rotarians in Lebanon illuminated the sea castle in Saida  an important archeological site  with the End Polio Now message. See a dramatic photo of this event  and why the Rotary Club of Saida is excited to be part of the effort to eradicate polio.  http://blog.rotary.org/2012/11/29/saida/

Do you have a great shot from a fundraiser  international project  the RI Convention  or a local club event? The Rotarian's 2013 photo contest is now underway. Enter up to three photos taken in 2012 or 2013 that illustrate the spirit of Rotary for a chance to win one of three cameras -- one Nikon digital SLR with lens or one of two Canon ultra-zoom point-and-shoots. Learn more at http://www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/071119_news_photocontestpromo.aspx

The Rotary Foundation's first gift was US$500 to the National Society for Crippled Children (Easter Seals) in 1929. Easter Seals was founded in 1921 by Rotarian Edgar F. Allen  of the Rotary Club of Elyria  Ohio  USA. Allen  Paul Harris (front  center) and other men who helped start the organization posed for this photograph in 1922.  It's Rotary Foundation Month. Learn more about Rotary Foundation grants at www.rotary.org/grants

Congratulations to all the Rotarians  including our General Secretary John Hewko  who rode in El Tour de Tucson and raised more than $US320 000 for our fight against polio.  Since 1985  Rotary and its global polio eradication partners have spearheaded the effort to rid the world of the crippling disease. If eradication fails and polio rebounds  up to 200 000 children per year could be paralyzed.    Read more at www.rotary.org/en/MediaAndNews/News/Pages/121119_news_polioride.aspx?fb

The Ride to End Polio in El Tour de Tucson in Arizona is 17 November. General Secretary John Hewko and more than 90 Rotarians  are participating. Together they've raised more than US$300 000 for polio eradication.  You can learn more about the ride at http://ow.ly/eawke.

It's World Interact Week and the program's 50th anniversary.  Interact clubs are sponsored by Rotary clubs  which provide support and guidance  but they are self-governing and self-supporting. Interact is open to people ages 12-18.  In this photo from 1964  the Interact Club of Ulverston  England  is holding a car wash to raise money for a public pool. Last month  we celebrated World Polio Day worldwide and helped raise awareness that we must finish our fight to End Polio Now!

Break out the colored pencils: Smithsonian Libraries has created a free  downloadable coloring booklet from pages in their collection. And we won't tell if you color outside the lines.   It pairs with a new Smithsonian Libraries exhibition  Color in a New Light  at Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History. It explores the many ways color connects our lives  from chemistry to couture. Learn more: http://s.si.edu/1WSeP3Z
No one can do #snowzilla better than a giant panda #blizzard2016

On this day in 1890  some 300 members of the Sioux Nation were killed in the Massacre at Wounded Knee.  The event is 125 years in the past  but survivors and descendants kept the history alive  grappling with the tragedy and reclaiming it for a brighter future.   On the anniversary  read more from a historian at Smithsonian's National Museum of the American Indian.

Whoa!! We have panda twins. 🐼🐼 Pandas often give birth to twins  but are usually only able to care for one at a time. For this reason  the Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute team have pulled the second cub and have placed it in an incubator. The "panda twin protocol" calls for each cub to have time to bond with its mother  so keepers will carefully swap each cub out from time to time.   This method has been used successfully in China for many years. National Zoo animal care staff have traveled to China in previous years to receive training in the twin raising method

Today is our 169th birthday! We were founded on Aug. 10  1846 by an act of Congress. We recently discovered the earliest known photos of our Castle--so early  the building is still under construction.

Lantern slide of #cherryblossoms along the Tidal Basin in Washington D.C. c. 1920.  Lantern slides are sort of an old school Instagram-- photographs were developed on small glass plates and hand painted in color. The slides were then projected onto a larger surface for viewing by an audience. This slide is from Smithsonian Gardens Archive of American Gardens.   More about the history of D.C. cherry blossoms and the archive: http://si-siris.blogspot.com/2014/03/a-century-of-cherry-blossom-watches.html  #cherryblossomsDC

BREAKING NEWS/CUTE ALERT!  Q: What looks like a cross between a house cat and a teddy bear? A: An Olinguito (oh-lin-GHEE-toe)—the first new carnivore discovered in the American continents in 35 years!  The 2-pound olinguito  with its large eyes and woolly orange-brown fur  is native to the cloud forests of Colombia and Ecuador  as its scientific name  “neblina” (Spanish for “fog”)  hints.   How are new species still being discovered in 2013? Kristofer Helgen  Smithsonian’s National Museum of Natural History’s head of mammals tells all in this Smithsonian Science story: http://s.si.edu/14LfgXb   (Photo by Mark Gurney)

Happy Birthday to...? The Smithsonian and LEGO!  Today we celebrate 167 years of history  art  culture and science while LEGO celebrates its 81st birthday.  The Smithsonian Castle model shown at top  constructed of more than 45 000 LEGO bricks  is now on display at the Smithsonian Castle.   (Photos: Smithsonian/Joanna Huxster)

We’re roaring with excitement! The Smithsonian's National Zoo welcomed two Sumatran tiger cubs Monday evening!  These cubs are a conservation success. Sumatran tigers are critically endangered in the wild  so every cub counts! Read all about the cubs and the births: http://s.si.edu/15ORAhD   We are giving Damai time to bond with and care for her cubs. They most likely will not be on exhibit until late fall. In the meantime  you can watch them grow on the Zoo’s tiger cub cams.

Today in 1960  the Woolworth lunch counter in Greensboro  North Carolina was finally desegregated after 6 months of sit-in protests.  Read more  from our National Museum of American History  where a section of this counter now resides: http://s.si.edu/15MyKq1  You can also bios and clips of the Greensboro 4 on the Smithsonian Channel's website: http://s.si.edu/19kXBXj  Photo courtesy of Greensboro News & Record

Today in 1969  astronauts Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong walked on the Moon and planted the American flag.  Read more  from National Museum of American History (http://s.si.edu/moonflag) and National Air and Space Museum  Smithsonian Institution (http://s.si.edu/buzzflag).  Photo: Neil Armstrong  National Aeronautics and Space Administration - NASA
Happy Birthday  U.S.A... and goodnight!  Photo: Eric Long  Smithsonian

Today  June 6  in 1944  Allied forces descended upon the beaches of Normandy  France in what is known as D-Day.  The D-Day invasion began with a dangerous attack by American paratroopers. Dropped behind enemy lines to soften up the German troops and to secure needed targets  the paratroopers knew that if the accompanying assault by sea failed -- there would be no rescue.  While nearly 7 000 Allied navy and merchant vessels pushed toward the beaches of Normandy  overhead  12 000 bombers and fighter planes poured inland. Their coordinated actions secured an Allied foothold in France that helped lead to the end of World War II.  More from our National Museum of American History: http://s.si.edu/11jwItj  Photo: Parachutes open overhead as waves of paratroops land in Holland during operations by the 1st Allied Airborne Army  Sept. 1944  courtesy of US National Archives.  Thanks to PBS's American Experience for partial text.  Clarification from Kathy Golden  associate curator  Division of Armed Forces History: Regarding "a dangerous attack by American paratroopers" in the text above  the phrase “Allied paratroopers” is more accurate (and among the Allied paratroopers were Americans  British  and Canadians).
